awd_titl_txt: CRII: SCH: Visualization for Better Medical Decision-Making
awd_abstract_narration:
This project develops visualization methods for communicating complex health risk data to patients. The project determines how the use of visual aids can impact decision-making and whether visual aids can cause, reinforce or mitigate biases. Additionally, the project identifies strategies people use when making medical decisions. Results of this work will have broad and varying impacts. The knowledge gained from this project will provide a better understanding of how people reason and make decisions with health statistics, and how we can improve or create novel designs for communicating such complex data beyond the medical field. The output of the project will be a database of tested visualization designs for supporting informed medical decision-making. 


Despite being fundamental components of evidence-based decision-making, medical statistics are notoriously unintuitive and arduous for people to understand. As a result, providing patient support for health decision-making has become a significant challenge for the medical community. This research addresses this problem by calling attention to synergies between medical risk communication and visualization theory. The project will create a theoretical framework for how visual representations impact decisions. The results will demonstrate how different designs can create, reinforce, or mitigate biases related to risk perception, and will identify individual characteristics that may mediate cognitive biases. Furthermore, the project will develop computational approaches for how people use visualization throughout the decision-making process and will determine which visual elements people tend to use or ignore.  Using medical risk communication as a test bed, this research will investigate core topics in the Visualization community and simultaneously make contributions to the medical community.  A core product of this project will be a web-based multi-dimensional recommendation system for health risk visualization. All publications, data, and source code will be publicly available.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This CRII project started with an interrogation into the connection between visualization design, biases, and individual differences in medical decision-making. Before the start of this project, there was empirical evidence that data encoding and individual differences in spatial ability ? a measure of someone's ability to manipulate 2- and 3-dimensional objects mentally ? mediate reasoning accuracy with medical statistics. 

The outcome of this CRII project contributed to understanding how text and visualization components might impact medical decision-making. We used eye-tracking to compare how people extract information from text and visualization. We provide evidence that visualization makes it easier to identify critical details while participants extracted data from the text more easily. Another manuscript sought to understand two text visualization integration forms: (i) different text and spatial visualization arrangements (layout), namely, vertical and slideshow, and (ii) interactive linking of text and visualization (linking). We found that participants performed significantly better with the slideshow layout on comprehension tasks. In addition, participants' recall was better with the slideshow layout under conditions with linking versus no linking.

Together, these findings led to a third project that sought to evaluate whether allowing users to interact with a static medical visualization can improve their reasoning. We show that adding interaction to a static statistical reasoning visualization does not improve participants' accuracy on a statistical reasoning task. In some cases, it can significantly detract from it. Moreover, we demonstrate that underlying visualization design modulates performance and that people with high versus low spatial ability respond differently to different interaction techniques and underlying base visualizations. Our work suggests that interaction is not as unambiguously good as we often believe; a well-designed static visualization can be as, if not more, effective than an interactive one.

An initial impetus for this CRII project was the acknowledgment that existing work primarily evaluated visualizations based on reasoning speed and accuracy and not decision-making. In light of this, we contributed a position paper and a book chapter discussing decision theories and providing suggestions to bridge the gap between the evaluation of decision-making in visualization and decision-science research. The goal was to question our knowledge limits and advocate for a more nuanced understanding of decision-making with visualization. Further, to investigate the impact of visualization on decision-making, we ran a large-scale gambling game that immersed participants in an environment where their actions impacted their bonuses. Participants entered a lottery or received guaranteed monetary gains based on five visualization designs. Finally, we model risk perception using our results and discuss how our findings can improve visualization selection.

The outcome of this CRII project was far-reaching, with a scientific impact beyond medical decision-making. In particular, this project contributed significantly to understanding individual differences in visualization. It produced a comprehensive review of the research perspectives and the personality traits and cognitive abilities, visualizations, tasks, and measures investigated in the literature. We published a manuscript summarizing existing scholarship and produced evidence-based reviews to spur future inquiry. Another outcome was an award-winning paper that examined the role of the personality trait locus of control in moderating complex analytic workflows. This paper analyzed a series of exercises with 22 trained intelligence analysts and sought to deepen our understanding of how individual differences modulate expert behavior in complex analysis tasks.

Finally, inquiries into how people interact with text and visualization components of medical visualization inspired broader contributions to the analysis of interaction log data. For example, one award-winning manuscript proposed a framework for inferring attention from passive observations of the user's click, allowing accurate predictions of future events. In another paper,  we pose user exploration modeling as a Bayesian model selection problem where we maintain a belief over numerous competing models that could explain user interactions. We validate our technique's ability to infer exploration bias, predict future interactions, and summarize an analytic session using user study datasets.
